Maintain a written pre-service curriculum for the PTFC program and make available to PTFC parents in-service training opportunities.
Treatment Home Capacity Requirements.
Not more than two out-of-home placement children may be placed in one eligible treatment home without the prior written approval from the Administration.
Requests to place a third out-of-home placement child, including a sibling, in the home must be made by the local department treatment program in writing to the Administration.
The local department PTFC program shall establish a written treatment plan for every treatment child in its program, which includes:
Role of the PTFC foster parent;
Role of the PTFC caseworker;
Specific tasks to be carried out by PTFC parents during placement;
Identification of treatment team members who will assist in the provision of planned care; and
Long-term goals of treatment, including:
Criteria for discharge;
Projected length of stay in the program;
Projected post-treatment; and
Treatment aftercare services.
The PTFC parent approved by the PTFC program shall:
Meet all of the requirements of a local department foster parent as prescribed by COMAR 07.02.25;
Meet all of the service and responsibility requirements of COMAR 07.02.21.10A and D;
Complete 8 hours of PTFC parent pre-service training in addition to the foster parent pre-service training requirements of COMAR 07.02.25; and
Complete 20 hours of in-service training annually.

section.heading: Payment to the Out-of-Home Placement Provider.

para.text: Amount Paid to the Provider.

The amount paid to the provider for care of the child is the amount determined by the standards established in Regulation .39 of this chapter, less any amount the child, who is planning for independent living, pays directly to the foster home from the child's own earnings as established in the service agreement.

Except for the child's own earnings, all resources shall be paid directly to the local department as reimbursement against the cost of the child's care. The amount that the local department pays to the foster parent or payee is not affected by any resource except the child's own earnings.
The provider payee is:
The foster parent in whose home the child has been placed;
The agency or institution from which care is being purchased for the child;
A vendor from whom purchase of certain goods or services has been authorized for the child according to established standards;
The child in a semi-independent living arrangement, or the child's payee.
Period Covered and Method of Payment to the Provider.

The period covered for regular payments shall be the calendar month or that part of the calendar month for which the local department has custody of the child, or has care and placement responsibilities for the child through a voluntary placement agreement, and the child is in the provider's care.

Temporary absence of the child from the foster home or group facility, such as for hospitalization or runaway status, with the intent for the child to return to the home or facility does not require recalculation of the amount of monthly board allowance unless the absence exceeds 30 days, in which case additional payment is not made. When the child returns, payment shall be resumed beginning with the date of return.
The amount of payment is calculated on a monthly basis and shall be paid by check or electronic transfer. In calculating the amount for a partial month's care, the following shall apply:
Board.
The amount for board shall be the per diem board rate times the number of days of care, counting the day the child goes into care, but not counting the day the child leaves care.
For a child who has moved during the month from one foster home to another, each foster home shall be paid the per diem rate for the days that the child was in each foster home, as set forth above.

Clothing and Other Items for Foster Family Care. For a child who is entering care, the full monthly amount for clothing may be allowed so long as the child is in the home for any part of the month, except that if an amount is allowed for initial clothing, then no other allowance for clothing may be made for that month.
Payment for Board and Clothing for Group Care.
The monthly clothing allowance for group care is combined with board and negotiated by the administration as a single rate. Payment is for actual monthly costs not to exceed this rate.

The amount of board and clothing allowance for care for a partial month is the actual per diem cost for board and clothing times the number of days of care but not counting the day the child leaves care. The per diem cost is the actual monthly cost for board and clothing times 12 divided by 365.
The initial clothing allowance is not available to group care, except for a child who is in a State institution.
Local Department Which Pays.
Payment shall be made by the local department which has responsibility for the child's placement through the court order or voluntary agreement.

When a child is placed in another local department's jurisdiction through intercounty placement, the local department which has legal responsibility for the child shall make the payment to the foster home.

section.heading: Correction of Payment Irregularities to the Out-of-Home Placement Provider.

para.text: Within 30 days of the knowledge of payment irregularity, the local department shall commence overpayment procedures.
Overpayment Procedures.
To correct an overpayment, the local department shall:
Determine the correct payment amount and take action to correct the continuing payment;
Calculate the total amount of the overpayment; and
Notify the provider in writing of the suspected overpayment amount within 10 days after determining that an overpayment exists.
The local department may not recoup an overpayment from a provider until the local department has notified the provider in writing that an overpayment has been identified.
The local department may propose to reduce, suspend, or terminate payment to correct the overpayment.
The provider may request a fair hearing to challenge the proposed action.
If the local department's decision following a fair hearing is upheld, the proposed reduction, suspension, or termination of the overpayment includes any overpayment made pending the decision.
Termination of payment does not relieve the provider of the obligation to reimburse the local department for any overpayment.
To obtain reimbursement, the local department shall:
Request repayment of the overpayment; and
If appropriate, initiate collection efforts in conformity with the procedure required to refer the debt to the Central Collection Unit, Department of Budget and Management.
If payment to the provider is subsequently reinstated, the local department shall recoup the amount of the overpayment as prescribed in §I of this regulation.
If a person repays the local department, the local department shall accept and credit the payment.
Fair Hearing.
Before the local department takes action to recover or recoup an overpayment, the local department shall advise the provider of the:
Right to a fair hearing; and
Procedure and time limit for requesting a fair hearing according to Regulation .38 of this chapter and COMAR 07.01.04.
The provider may request a fair hearing to challenge the:
Decision of the local department that an overpayment occurred;
Amount or cause of the overpayment; or
Proposed method to repay the overpayment.
Within 30 days following a fair hearing, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall notify the individual in writing of the:
Agency decision; and
Reasons for the decision.
Suspected Fraud Procedures.
If the local department determines that a case is one of suspected fraud as defined in Regulation .03B of this chapter, the local department shall refer the case to the:
The Department's Office of the Inspector General (OIG); or
State's attorney's office (SAO).
Before the local department refers a case to the (OIG) or SAO, the referral document shall be approved by a supervisor or the director's designee.
After making the referral, the local department:
Shall inform the OIG or the SAO of any new facts or changed circumstances in the case;
Shall provide access to relevant information in its possession to the assigned investigators; and
May not notify a provider of the referral to the OIG or the SAO but may answer "yes" or "no" when the provider asks whether a referral was made.
Recoupment Procedures.
Recoupment.
Except as noted in §I(1)(b) of this regulation, the local department shall take action to recoup an overpayment and determine with the provider:
The total amount to be recouped; and
An amount to be recouped through a monthly deduction from the continuing payment for as many months as are necessary until the overpayment is repaid.
In the case of foster care providers, the amount recouped may not reduce the personal needs allowance by more than 50 percent of the monthly foster care payment rate.
Procedures for Dual Jurisdictions. When a provider moves from one local department jurisdiction to another, the:
Forwarding local department shall notify the receiving local department of the recoupment process; and
Receiving local department shall continue the recoupment process, if appropriate, and credit all money recouped to the program funding source according to the Department's instructions.
A local department may establish a supplement to the State standard to be used to meet special needs, provided that the:
Supplement is met by local funds and is included in the fiscal agreement between the Department of Human Services and the local government;

Supplement is applied uniformly to homes located within the local department's jurisdiction and to specific homes located in the jurisdictions of other local departments, when the local department which makes a supplemental payment places a child in a home located in the jurisdiction of another local department;
Supplemented items are not included in the State standard.
The plan to supplement shall be approved as local policy by the Social Services Administration before being put into effect. The plan shall specify the:
Amount budgeted for the supplement;
Reasons for needing it; and
Plan for assuring that the amounts in excess of the State maximum are paid from local funds.

section.heading: Liability Insurance and Reimbursement for Loss to Foster Parents.

para.text: Insurance.

The Department shall, under certain conditions, provide liability insurance premiums from State funds, for foster parents who care for children under the direct supervision of the local departments or under the direct supervision of licensed private child placement agencies. The insurance shall cover:
Bodily injury and property damage that a foster child causes to an individual or the property of a person other than a foster parent; and
Actions brought against the foster parents by the child's parents or legal guardians for any accident to the foster child.
Excluded from coverage are claims for:
Alienation of affections;
Accidents involving vehicles which are licensed or intended for road use; and
Payment to the foster parents for injury or damage caused by the foster child to the foster parent which is otherwise covered by insurance.
Reimbursement.
The Secretary of Human Services shall reimburse a foster parent for costs of bodily injury or property damage that the child causes to the foster parent.
Excluded for reimbursement to the foster parent are claims in which:
The actions of the foster parent contributed substantially to the bodily injury or property damage sustained; or
If available, the foster parent's insurance covers the bodily injury or property damage sustained.
The maximum amount of reimbursement is $5,000. Payments in excess of $2,000 require approval by the State Board of Public Works.

At the time of placement, the local department shall give to each parent or legal guardian of a child in out-of-home placement written and verbal notification of the right and methods of requesting and obtaining a fair hearing.

The local department shall notify the parents or legal guardian of its intent to take any action which will deny, reduce, suspend, or terminate visits with the child, reunification services, or aftercare services, and of the right and methods of requesting and obtaining a fair hearing on that intended action.
A fair hearing need not be held on any decision which has been, or may only be, determined by a court.
In all other respects, the provisions of COMAR 07.01.04 apply to fair hearings on out-of-home placement services.
